standard_metadata.standard_description: Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, and solve word problems involving division of fractions by fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.

question.content: Iekika is $\dfrac{3}{2}\,\text{m}$ tall, which is $\dfrac{4}{5}$ as tall as Shanika.  **What does $\dfrac{3}{2} \div \dfrac{4}{5}$ represent in this situation?**

hints.content: ###Meanings of multiplication and division  There are three common meanings of multiplication.  $\begin{align} \text{(number of groups)} \times \text{(size of group)} &= \text{total}\\\\ \text{(original value)} \times \text{(comparison factor)} &= \text{(new value)}\\\\ \text{base} \times \text{height} &= \text{(rectangular area)} \end{align}$  Which of these meanings makes sense for our context? Which value fills each role?  Once we have a multiplication equation that represents the situation, we can rewrite it as an equivalent division equation. Then we'll know the meaning of the quotient.

###Multiplication equation  Iekika is $\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{5}}$ as tall as Shanika, so $\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{5}}$ is a comparison factor.  We are comparing to Shanika, so Shanika's height is the original measurement. Iekika's height, $\purpleD{\dfrac{3}{2}\,\text{m}}$, is the new measurement.  $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{(original value)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(comparison factor)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(new value)}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(Shanika's height)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(comparison factor)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(Iekika's height)}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(Shanika's height)}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{4}{5}} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{3}{2}} \end{align}$
###Division equation  Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation.  $\blueE{\text{(Shanika's height)}} = \purpleD{\dfrac{3}{2}} \div \maroonD{\dfrac{4}{5}}$
###Conclusion  So the expression $\purpleD{\dfrac{3}{2}} \div \maroonD{\dfrac{4}{5}}$ represents Shanika's height.

question.content: Kakalina's class painted a  to honor their ancestors. The mural covers a $12\dfrac{1}{8}\,\text{m}$ long, rectangular wall. It has an area of $36\dfrac{3}{8}\,\text{m}^2$.  **What does $36\dfrac{3}{8} \div 12\dfrac{1}{8}$ represent in this situation?**

options.content: The fraction of the wall covered by the mural
The volume of paint per square meter of the mural

hints.content: ###Meanings of multiplication and division  There are three common meanings of multiplication.  $\begin{align} \text{(number of groups)} \times \text{(size of group)} &= \text{total}\\\\ \text{(original value)} \times \text{(comparison factor)} &= \text{(new value)}\\\\ \text{base} \times \text{height} &= \text{(rectangular area)} \end{align}$  Which of these meanings makes sense for our context? Which value fills each role?  Once we have a multiplication equation that represents the situation, we can rewrite it as an equivalent division equation. Then we'll know the meaning of the quotient.

###Multiplication equation  The mural has an area of $\purpleD{36\dfrac{3}{8}\,\text{m}^2}$. The base of the mural is $\blueE{12\dfrac{1}{8}\,\text{m}}$ long, like the wall it covers. The height, in meters, of the mural is unknown.  $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{base}} \times \maroonD{\text{height}} &= \purpleD{\text{(rectangular area)}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(mural length)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(mural height)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(mural area)}}\\\\ \blueE{12\dfrac{1}{8}} \times \maroonD{\text{(mural height)}} &= \purpleD{36\dfrac{3}{8}} \end{align}$
###Division equation  Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation.  $\maroonD{\text{(mural height)}} = \purpleD{36\dfrac{3}{8}} \div \blueE{12\dfrac{1}{8}}$
###Conclusion  So the expression $\purpleD{36\dfrac{3}{8}} \div \blueE{12\dfrac{1}{8}}$ represents the height of the mural.

question.content: Jamaar helped in the community garden for $\dfrac{21}{10}$ hours this week. That was $2\dfrac{4}{5}$ equal-length shifts, because Jamaar stopped early one day when it started to rain.  **What does $\dfrac{21}{10} \div 2\dfrac{4}{5}$ represent in this situation?**

options.content: The fraction of a shift Jamaar helped on the day it rained
The number of shifts per hour
The fraction of the week that Jamaar spent in the garden

hints.content: ###Meanings of multiplication and division  There are three common meanings of multiplication.  $\begin{align} \text{(number of groups)} \times \text{(size of group)} &= \text{total}\\\\ \text{(original value)} \times \text{(comparison factor)} &= \text{(new value)}\\\\ \text{base} \times \text{height} &= \text{(rectangular area)} \end{align}$  Which of these meanings makes sense for our context? Which value fills each role?  Once we have a multiplication equation that represents the situation, we can rewrite it as an equivalent division equation. Then we'll know the meaning of the quotient.

###Multiplication equation  Jamaar helped for a total of $\purpleD{\dfrac{21}{10}}$ hours. Jamaar helped for $\blueE{2\dfrac{3}{4}}$ shifts, and each shift is a group of hours. The group size, the number of hours per shift, is unknown.  $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{(number of groups)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(size of group)}} &= \purpleD{\text{total}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(number of shifts)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(hours per shift)}} &= \purpleD{\text{total hours}}\\\\ \blueE{2\dfrac{3}{4}} \times \maroonD{\text{(hours per shift)}} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{21}{10}} \end{align}$
###Division equation  Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation.  $\maroonD{\text{(hours per shift)}} = \purpleD{\dfrac{21}{10}} \div \blueE{2\dfrac{3}{4}}$
###Conclusion  So the expression $\purpleD{\dfrac{21}{10}} \div \blueE{2\dfrac{3}{4}}$ represents the length of each shift.

question.content: A restaurant has $5\dfrac{3}{8}$ pitchers of .  Jada said $5\dfrac{3}{8} \div 1\dfrac{1}{8}$ could represent the number of total servings if there are $1\dfrac{1}{8}$ servings per pitcher.  Latanya said $5\dfrac{3}{8} \div 1\dfrac{1}{8}$ could represent the average number of pitchers the restaurant serves per day if it takes $1\dfrac{1}{8}$ days to serve all of the horchata.  **Whose interpretation makes sense in this context?**

hints.content: ###Meanings of multiplication and division  There are three common meanings of multiplication.  $\begin{align} \text{(number of groups)} \times \text{(size of group)} &= \text{total}\\\\ \text{(original value)} \times \text{(comparison factor)} &= \text{(new value)}\\\\ \text{base} \times \text{height} &= \text{(rectangular area)} \end{align}$  Let's decide which meaning each person used. Then we can rewrite the equation in division form. Finally, we can fill in the known numbers to see whether each expression makes sense.

###Jada's interpretation  Jada says the group size is $\maroonD{1\dfrac{1}{8}}$ servings per pitcher. Each pitcher is a group of servings, so there are $\blueE{5\dfrac{3}{8}}$ groups. There is an unknown total.  $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{(number of groups)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(size of group)}} &= \purpleD{\text{total}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(number of pitchers)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(servings per pitcher)}} &= \purpleD{\text{total servings}}\\\\ \blueE{5\dfrac{3}{8}} \times \maroonD{1\dfrac{1}{8}} &= \purpleD{\text{total servings}} \end{align}$  Jada should have said that $\blueE{5\dfrac{3}{8}} \times \maroonD{1\dfrac{1}{8}}$ could represent the number of total servings, but she used division instead.  No, Jada's interpretation *does not* make sense in this context.

###Latanya's interpretation  Latanya says the restaurant uses a total of $\purpleD{5\dfrac{3}{8}}$ pitchers. Each day the restaurant uses a group of pitchers, so there are $\blueE{1\dfrac{1}{8}}$ groups. There is an unknown group size (the number of pitchers per day).  $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{(number of groups)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(size of group)}} &= \purpleD{\text{total}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(number of days)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(pitchers per day)}} &= \purpleD{\text{total pitchers}}\\\\ \blueE{1\dfrac{1}{8}} \times \maroonD{\text{(pitchers per day)}} &= \purpleD{5\dfrac{3}{8}} \end{align}$  We can rewrite as an equivalent division equation.  $\purpleD{5\dfrac{3}{8}} \div \blueE{1\dfrac{1}{8}} = \maroonD{\text{(pitchers per day)}}$  Yes, Latanya's interpretation *does* make sense in this context.
###Conclusion  Only Latanya's interpretation makes sense in this context.

question.content: An electrician plans to install solar panels on a rectangular section of roof with an area of $69\,\text{m}^2$.  Tyriq said $69 \div 7\dfrac{1}{10}$ could represent the length of the section if the section is $7\dfrac{1}{10}\,\text{m}$ across.  Corbin said $69 \div 7\dfrac{1}{10}$ could represent the number of solar panels that would fit if each panel was $7\dfrac{1}{10}\,\text{m}$ long.  **Whose interpretation makes sense in this context?**

hints.content: ###Meanings of multiplication and division  There are three common meanings of multiplication.  $\begin{align} \text{(number of groups)} \times \text{(size of group)} &= \text{total}\\\\ \text{(original value)} \times \text{(comparison factor)} &= \text{(new value)}\\\\ \text{base} \times \text{height} &= \text{(rectangular area)} \end{align}$  Let's decide which meaning each person used. Then we can rewrite the equation in division form. Finally, we can fill in the known numbers to see whether each expression makes sense.

###Tyriq's interpretation  The section of roof has an area of $\purpleD{69\,\text{m}^2}$. Tyriq says that the section is $\blueE{7\dfrac{1}{10}\,\text{m}}$ across. There is an unknown second side length, in meters.  $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{base}} \times \maroonD{\text{height}} &= \purpleD{\text{(rectangular area)}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(distance across section)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(length of section)}} &= \purpleD{\text{section area}}\\\\ \blueE{7\dfrac{1}{10}} \times \maroonD{\text{(length of section)}} &= \purpleD{69} \end{align}$  We can rewrite as an equivalent division equation.  $\purpleD{69} \div \blueE{7\dfrac{1}{10}} = \maroonD{\text{(length of section)}}$  Yes, Tyriq's interpretation *does* make sense in this context.

###Corbin's interpretation  Corbin is trying to find an unknown number of groups, the number of solar panels. Each solar panel is a group of lengths, $\blueE{7\dfrac{1}{10}\,\text{m}}$. However, Corbin uses the area $\purpleD{69\,\text{m}^2}$ instead of the length of the section as the total.  Corbin should either have compared the *area* of each panel to the total area, or compared the *length* of each panel to the total length of the section.   Then the group numbers would be the maximum number of solar panels that *might* fit, because a fraction of a solar panel doesn't make sense in this context.  No, Corbin's interpretation *does not* make sense in this context.
###Conclusion  Only Tyriq's interpretation makes sense in this context.

question.content: A class collected $2{,}650\,\text{L}$ of materials to recycle.  Reginald said that $2{,}650 \div 49\dfrac{1}{10}$ could represent the volume of each bag if the class filled $49\dfrac{1}{10}$ bags with material to recycle.  Peni said that $2{,}650 \div 49\dfrac{1}{10}$ could represent the number of containers the class filled if each container holds $49\dfrac{1}{10}\,\text{L}$ of material.  **Whose interpretation makes sense in this context?**

hints.content: ###Meanings of multiplication and division  There are three common meanings of multiplication.  $\begin{align} \text{(number of groups)} \times \text{(size of group)} &= \text{total}\\\\ \text{(original value)} \times \text{(comparison factor)} &= \text{(new value)}\\\\ \text{base} \times \text{height} &= \text{(rectangular area)} \end{align}$  Let's decide which meaning each person used. Then we can rewrite the equation in division form. Finally, we can fill in the known numbers to see whether each expression makes sense.

###Reginald's interpretation  Reginald says the class collected a total of $\purpleD{2{,}650\,\text{L}}$ of material. Each bag holds a group of liters, so there are $\blueE{49\dfrac{1}{10}}$ groups. There is an unknown group size (the number of liters per bag).  $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{(number of groups)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(size of group)}} &= \purpleD{\text{total}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(number of bags)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(liters per bag)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(total liters)}}\\\\ \blueE{49\dfrac{1}{10}} \times \maroonD{\text{(liters per bag)}} &= \purpleD{2{,}650} \end{align}$  We can rewrite as an equivalent division equation.  $\purpleD{2{,}650} \div \blueE{49\dfrac{1}{10}} = \maroonD{\text{(liters per bag)}}$  Yes, Reginald's interpretation *does* make sense in this context.

###Peni's interpretation  Peni says the class collected a total of $\purpleD{2{,}650\,\text{L}}$ of material. Each container holds a group of liters, so the group size is $\maroonD{49\dfrac{1}{10}}$ liters per container. There is an unknown number of groups (the number of containers).  $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{(number of groups)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(size of group)}} &= \purpleD{\text{total}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(number of containers)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(liters per container)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(total liters)}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(number of containers)}} \times \maroonD{49\dfrac{1}{10}} &= \purpleD{2{,}650} \end{align}$  We can rewrite as an equivalent division equation.  $\purpleD{2{,}650} \div \maroonD{49\dfrac{1}{10}} = \blueE{\text{(number of containers)}}$  Yes, Peni's interpretation *does* make sense in this context.
###Conclusion  Both Reginald's and Peni's interpretations make sense in this context.

question.content: Kalani had a length of $3\dfrac{1}{3}\,\text{m}$ of cloth and cut $2\dfrac{5}{12}$ strips the full width of the cloth. Let $\ell$ represent the length, in meters, of each whole strip.  **Select $1$ multiplication and $1$ division equation to represent the relationship.**

hints.content: ###Meanings of multiplication and division  There are three common meanings of multiplication.  $\begin{align} \text{(number of groups)} \times \text{(size of group)} &= \text{total}\\\\ \text{(original value)} \times \text{(comparison factor)} &= \text{(new value)}\\\\ \text{base} \times \text{height} &= \text{(rectangular area)} \end{align}$  Which of these meanings makes sense for our context? Which value or variable fills each role?  Once we have a multiplication equation that represents the situation, we can rewrite it as an equivalent division equation.

###Multiplication equation  Kalani has a total length of $\purpleD{3\dfrac{1}{3}\,\text{m}}$ of cloth. Each strip is a group of meters, so there are $\blueE{2\dfrac{5}{12}}$ groups. There is an unknown group size of $\maroonD{\ell}$ meters per strip.  $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{(number of groups)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(size of group)}} &= \purpleD{\text{total}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(number of strips)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(length per strip)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(total length)}}\\\\ \blueE{2\dfrac{5}{12}} \times \maroonD{\ell} &= \purpleD{3\dfrac{1}{3}} \end{align}$

###Division equations  We can rewrite the multiplication equation as two equivalent division equations.  $\begin{align} \purpleD{3\dfrac{1}{3}} \div \blueE{2\dfrac{5}{12}} &=\maroonD{\ell} \\\\ \purpleD{3\dfrac{1}{3}} \div \maroonD{\ell} &= \blueE{2\dfrac{5}{12}} \end{align}$  Only one of these equations was an option.

###Conclusion  Of the given equations, the following two represent the relationship.  - $\blueE{2\dfrac{5}{12}} \times \maroonD{\ell} = \purpleD{3\dfrac{1}{3}}$  * $\purpleD{3\dfrac{1}{3}} \div \blueE{2\dfrac{5}{12}} =\maroonD{\ell}$

question.content: Anastacio distributed $4\dfrac{4}{5}\,\text{kg}$ of seed among several bird feeders. He put $\dfrac{3}{5}\,\text{kg}$ of seed in each feeder. Let $f$ represent the number of bird feeders that Anastacio filled.  **Select $1$ multiplication and $1$ division equation to represent the relationship.**

hints.content: ###Meanings of multiplication and division  There are three common meanings of multiplication.  $\begin{align} \text{(number of groups)} \times \text{(size of group)} &= \text{total}\\\\ \text{(original value)} \times \text{(comparison factor)} &= \text{(new value)}\\\\ \text{base} \times \text{height} &= \text{(rectangular area)} \end{align}$  Which of these meanings makes sense for our context? Which value or variable fills each role?  Once we have a multiplication equation that represents the situation, we can rewrite it as an equivalent division equation.

###Multiplication equation  Anastacio has a total mass of $\purpleD{4\dfrac{4}{5}\,\text{kg}}$ of seed. He spread the seed among $\blueE{f}$ bird feeders. There is a group size of $\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}\,\text{kg}}$ of seed per feeder.  $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{(number of groups)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(size of group)}} &= \purpleD{\text{total}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(number of feeders)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(seed mass per feeder)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(total seed mass)}}\\\\ \blueE{f} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}} &= \purpleD{4\dfrac{4}{5}} \end{align}$

###Division equations  We can rewrite the multiplication equation as two equivalent division equations.  $\begin{align} \purpleD{4\dfrac{4}{5}} \div \blueE{f} &=\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}}\\\\ \purpleD{4\dfrac{4}{5}} \div \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}} &= \blueE{f} \end{align}$  Only one of these equations was an option.

###Conclusion  Of the given equations, the following two represent the relationship.  - $\blueE{f} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}} = \purpleD{4\dfrac{4}{5}}$  * $\purpleD{4\dfrac{4}{5}} \div \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}} = \blueE{f}$

question.content: To make marbled paper, Shannon filled a rectangular $\dfrac{279}{10}\,\text{cm}$ by $\dfrac{178}{10}\,\text{cm}$ dish with water. Then they gently swirled paint on top of the water. Let $a$ represent the area of the dish.  **Select $1$ multiplication and $1$ division equation to represent the relationship.**

images.alt: Person holding a marbled sheet of paper with a rose painted on it.

hints.content: ###Meanings of multiplication and division  There are three common meanings of multiplication.  $\begin{align} \text{(number of groups)} \times \text{(size of group)} &= \text{total}\\\\ \text{(original value)} \times \text{(comparison factor)} &= \text{(new value)}\\\\ \text{base} \times \text{height} &= \text{(rectangular area)} \end{align}$  Which of these meanings makes sense for our context? Which value or variable fills each role?  Once we have a multiplication equation that represents the situation, we can rewrite it as an equivalent division equation.

###Multiplication equation  The rectangular dish has two known measurements: $\maroonD{\dfrac{279}{10}\,\text{cm}}$ and $\blueE{\dfrac{178}{10}\,\text{cm}}$.  (We don't know the depth of the dish.) Since we could turn the dish in different directions, either could be the base or the height. The unknown area of the dish is $\purpleD{a}$.  $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{base}} \times \maroonD{\text{height}} &= \purpleD{\text{(rectangular area)}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(side length 1)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(side length 2)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(dish area)}}\\\\ \blueE{\dfrac{178}{10}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{279}{10}} &= \purpleD{a} \end{align}$

###Division equations  We can rewrite the multiplication equation as two equivalent division equations.  $\begin{align} \purpleD{a} \div \blueE{\dfrac{178}{10}}  &=\maroonD{\dfrac{279}{10}} \\\\ \purpleD{a} \div \maroonD{\dfrac{279}{10}}  &= \blueE{\dfrac{178}{10}} \end{align}$  Only one of these equations was an option.

###Conclusion  Of the given equations, the following two represent the relationship.  - $\blueE{\dfrac{178}{10}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{279}{10}} = \purpleD{a}$  * $\purpleD{a} \div \blueE{\dfrac{178}{10}}  =\maroonD{\dfrac{279}{10}} $

question.content: A cress seed took $\dfrac{8}{7}$ of a week to . An artichoke seed took $\dfrac{17}{7}$ weeks to sprout.  **What question does $\dfrac{8}{7} \div \dfrac{17}{7}$ help us answer in this situation?**

options.content: How many times as long did the cress seed take to sprout as the artichoke seed?
How many times as long did the artichoke seed take to sprout as the cress seed?
How much longer did the cress seed take to germinate than the artichoke seed?
How much longer did the artichoke seed take to germinate than the cress seed?

hints.content: ###Meanings of multiplication and division  There are three common meanings of multiplication.  $\begin{align} \text{(number of groups)} \times \text{(size of group)} &= \text{total}\\\\ \text{(original value)} \times \text{(comparison factor)} &= \text{(new value)}\\\\ \text{base} \times \text{height} &= \text{(rectangular area)} \end{align}$  Which of these meanings makes sense for our context? Which value fills each role?  Once we have a multiplication equation that represents the situation, we can rewrite it as an equivalent division equation. Then we'll know the meaning of the quotient.

###Multiplication equation  We have two values that we're comparing, the sprouting times for the cress seed and the artichoke seed.  $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{(original value)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(comparison factor)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(new value)}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(sprouting time 1)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(comparison factor)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(sprouting time 2)}} \end{align}$  Our unknown is the comparison factor. Let's rewrite the multiplication equation as an equivalent division equation. Then we can fill in the values we know.

###Division equation  The cress took $\purpleD{\dfrac{8}{7}}$ weeks to sprout, and the artichoke took $\blueE{\dfrac{17}{7}}$ weeks.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\text{(comparison factor)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(sprouting time 2)}} \div \blueE{\text{(sprouting time 1)}} \\\\ \maroonD{\text{(comparison factor)}} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{8}{7}} \div \blueE{\dfrac{17}{7}}\\\\ \maroonD{\text{(comparison factor)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(cress sprouting time)}} \div \blueE{\text{(artichoke sprouting time)}} \end{align}$  The new value was the cress sprouting time, and we were comparing to the artichoke sprouting time.
###Conclusion  So the expression $\purpleD{\dfrac{8}{7}} \div \blueE{\dfrac{17}{7}}$ answers the question, "How many times as long did the *cress seed* take to sprout as the *artichoke seed*?"

question.content: A regular hippo and a pygmy hippo were recently born. The regular hippo had a mass of $25\dfrac{1}{2}\,\text{kg}$ at birth.  Kaipo said that $25\dfrac{1}{2} \div 5\dfrac{3}{10}$ could represent the mass of the pygmy hippo if the regular hippo massed $5\dfrac{3}{10}$ times as much as the pygmy hippo at birth.  Normani said that if the pygmy hippo massed $5\dfrac{3}{10}\,\text{kg}$ at birth, then the regular hippo massed $25\dfrac{1}{2} \div 5\dfrac{3}{10}$ times as much as the pygmy hippo.  **Whose interpretation makes sense in this context?**

hints.content: ###Meanings of multiplication and division  There are three common meanings of multiplication.  $\begin{align} \text{(number of groups)} \times \text{(size of group)} &= \text{total}\\\\ \text{(original value)} \times \text{(comparison factor)} &= \text{(new value)}\\\\ \text{base} \times \text{height} &= \text{(rectangular area)} \end{align}$  Let's decide which meaning each person used. Then we can rewrite the equation in division form. Finally, we can fill in the known numbers to see whether each expression makes sense.

###Kaipo's interpretation  Kaipo is comparing to the pygmy hippo's mass, so there is an unknown original mass. Kaipo says there is a comparison factor of $\maroonD{5\dfrac{3}{10}}$. The regular hippo's mass at birth, $\purpleD{25\dfrac{1}{2}\,\text{kg}}$, is the new mass.  $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{(original value)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(comparison factor)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(new value)}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(pygmy hippo's mass)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(comparison factor)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(regular hippo's mass)}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(pygmy hippo's mass)}} \times \maroonD{5\dfrac{3}{10}} &= \purpleD{25\dfrac{1}{2}} \end{align}$  We can rewrite as an equivalent division equation.  $\purpleD{25\dfrac{1}{2}} \div \maroonD{5\dfrac{3}{10}} = \blueE{\text{(pygmy hippo's mass)}}$  Yes, Kaipo's interpretation *does* make sense in this context.

###Normani's interpretation  Normani is comparing to the pygmy hippo's mass, so the original mass is $\blueE{5\dfrac{3}{10}\,\text{kg}}$. The regular hippo's mass at birth, $\purpleD{25\dfrac{1}{2}\,\text{kg}}$, is the new mass. There is an unknown comparison factor.  $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{(original value)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(comparison factor)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(new value)}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(pygmy hippo's mass)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(comparison factor)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(regular hippo's mass)}}\\\\ \blueE{\blueE{5\dfrac{3}{10}}} \times \maroonD{\text{(comparison factor)}} &= \purpleD{25\dfrac{1}{2}} \end{align}$  We can rewrite as an equivalent division equation.  $\purpleD{25\dfrac{1}{2}} \div \blueE{\blueE{5\dfrac{3}{10}}} = \maroonD{\text{(comparison factor)}}$  Yes, Normani's interpretation *does* make sense in this context.
###Conclusion  Both Kaipo's and Normani's interpretations make sense in this context.

question.content: In a garden, $\dfrac{5}{6}$ of the area is filled with native plants. The native plants take up $\dfrac{107}{4}\,\text{m}^2$. Let $g$ represent the total area of the garden.  **Select $1$ multiplication and $1$ division equation to represent the relationship.**

hints.content: ###Meanings of multiplication and division  There are three common meanings of multiplication.  $\begin{align} \text{(number of groups)} \times \text{(size of group)} &= \text{total}\\\\ \text{(original value)} \times \text{(comparison factor)} &= \text{(new value)}\\\\ \text{base} \times \text{height} &= \text{(rectangular area)} \end{align}$  Which of these meanings makes sense for our context? Which value or variable fills each role?  Once we have a multiplication equation that represents the situation, we can rewrite it as an equivalent division equation.

###Multiplication equation  The native plants fill $\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}}$ of the area of the garden, so $\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}}$ is a comparison factor.  We are comparing to the area of the garden, so the area of the garden, $\blueE{g}$, is the original measurement. The area filled with native plants, $\purpleD{\dfrac{107}{4}\,\text{m}^2}$, is the new measurement.  $\begin{align} \blueE{\text{(original value)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(comparison factor)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(new value)}}\\\\ \blueE{\text{(area of garden)}} \times \maroonD{\text{(comparison factor)}} &= \purpleD{\text{(area of native plants)}}\\\\ \blueE{g} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}} &= \purpleD{\dfrac{107}{4}} \end{align}$

###Division equations  We can rewrite the multiplication equation as two equivalent division equations.  $\begin{align} \purpleD{\dfrac{107}{4}} \div \blueE{g} &=\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}}\\\\ \purpleD{\dfrac{107}{4}} \div \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}} &= \blueE{g} \end{align}$  Only one of these equations was an option.

###Conclusion  Of the given equations, the following two represent the relationship.  - $\blueE{g} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}} = \purpleD{\dfrac{107}{4}}$  * $\purpleD{\dfrac{107}{4}} \div \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}} = \blueE{g}$
